“Te EMO Journal VoL2 No. yp.499=404, 1983,

Purification of muscarinic acetylcholine receptors

by affinity chromatography

 

C. André, J.P. De Backer?, J.C. Guillet’,
P. Vanderheyden!, G. Vauquelin’ and A.D, Strosberg?
"Deparment of Prottin Chemistry (bunt Pathological Biochem),
Fice University of Bross, 65 Paardenstant, 1640 Sint Genesis Roos,
Belin, and *Laboratry of Molecular Immunology, Jacques Monod
Insitute, CNRS, Uniersiy Pars VIl, Tout 3, Plce Tass
1525 Pars Codex 5, France

Communicated by 8. Avraneae

Reverd on 9 December 182; revised on 6 February 1982

Calf forebrain homogenates contain 2.8 pM muscarinic
acetylcholine receptors per mg of protein. [HJAntagonist
saturation binding experiments under equi

revealed a single clas of sites with equilibrium dissoctation
Constants of 0.82 nM for [H1}dexetimide and 0.095 nM for
CHjquinuctidiny! benzilate, Displacement binding studies
with agonists revealed the presence of fow and high affinity
sites. Here we describe the solubilization of muscarinic acetyl-
choline receptors with digitonin and their purification by
affinity chromatography using an affinity gel which consisted
Of dexetimide coupled (0 Aff-Gel 10 (ie. carboxy N-hyd-
roxysuecinimide esters linked via a 1mm spacer arm {0
agarose beads). Purified proteins were obtained by specie
elution with muscarinie drugs, ie., the antagonist atropine
‘and the irreversible ligand propylbenzilylchotine mustard.
'SDS-polyaerslamide gel electrophoresis of the radiofodinated
purified preparations revealed 2 major 70-K protein,

Key words: bovine forebrain/dexetimide/digitonin

 

 

 

 

 

  

 

Introduction

‘The neurotransmitter acetylcholine elicits rapid responses
by interacting with nicotinic receptors (aACHRS) and slower
effects via muscarinic receptors (mACHRs). Muscarinic
responses are observed in the central and peripheral nervous,
system as wel asin muscle and in glands and represent a large:
Proportion of the acetylcholine-mediated effects, Due to the
extraordinarily high number of nAChRs found in the post
synaptic membrane of the electromotor synapses of electric
fish, knowledge of the mechanism and structure of nACHRS.
hhas increased tremendously in recent years (Changeux, 1981).
‘Advances in research on mACHRS have been much less rapid.
This is due to the lower concentration of mACHRS, together,
with the fact that these receptors have not yet been purified.

Earlier radioligand binding studies revealed that mACHRS
are discrete membrane components which recognize an-
tagonist and agonist molecules (Gorissen et al, 1978; Birdsall,
et al., 1979; Haga, 1980). As is the case with many other
receptor systems, the two types of ligands appear to differ in
their mechanisms of interaction in the following way: only
agonists induce receptor desensitization in intact cel prepara-
tions (Klein et al. 1979; Simon and Klein, 1979); the reoep-
tors are composed of different subpopulations with the same
affinity for antagonists but different affinities for agonists
Birdsall e¢ at, 1978; Ehlert et a., 1981); guanine nucleotides

 

 

 

 

 

 

‘To whom rep requess shoud be sent.

© IRL Press Limos, Oxford, England,

and Mg?* ions have opposite effects on agonist affinity but
‘no effect on antagonist binding (Ehlert er ai., 1981; Wei and
Sulakhe, 1980; Sokolovsky et af., 1980); and finally, agonists
but not antagonists induce conformational changes in the
receptors (Vauguelin et al, 1982).

'mACA|RS have been successfully solubilized with a wide
variety of detergents, of which digitonin appears to be the
‘most effective (Gorissen et al., 1981; Ruess and Lieflander,
1979; Hurko, 1978; Aaronstam er al. 1978; Repke and Mat™
thies, 1980). An affinity gel with high affinity for mACHRS
(Repke et al. 1980) has been described recently and a
Durifcation of hydrophobic MACHR and nACHR proteins
‘was attempted carlier (Barrantes ef al, 1975). We report here
the first successful purification of mACHRS. These receptors
were solubilized with digitonin, purified by absorption on an
affinity get with dexetimide followed by seletive elution with
the MACHR antagonist atropine or with the highly specific
Inreversible ligand propylbenzilyicholine mustard (PrBCM).
‘The radioiodinated purified proteins were analysed by SDS-
polyacrytamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE),

 

Results

Ligand binding characteristics of the membrane-bound and
solubilized mAChRs

55 st 10% membrane proteins and 15 -+ 5% of the total
specific [?H}dexetimide or (?Hquinucldinyl berzilate (QNB)
binding activity were recovered in the supernatant of a 1%
(w/\) digitonin-treated membrane suspension.

‘The equilibrium saturation binding data of studies on
membrane-bound (mm) and solubilized (8) mACHRs with
Plijdexetimide are given in Figure 1A and B, respectively.
Binding is saturable for both preparations: Braxiqy ~ 2-8
PM/mg of protein; Bmax = 0.95 pM/mg of protein, The
derived Seatchard plots are rectilinear (jg) = 0.98; ig =
0.99) indicating that only one clas of dexelinide binding ites
is present in both preparations. Equilibrium dissociation con.
stants of 0.82 nM (Ky) and 4.5 nM (Kpya), respectively,
are obtained from the Satchard plots. Simlarly, PH]QNB
binding is saturable in both preparations. The Scatchard plots
are rectilinear (jg) = O91 and ry = 0.95) and the
equilibrium dissociation constants eqUal 0.095 RM (Kpyqs)
and 0.072 0M (Kya), respectively,

Agonists bind to two different classes of binding sites on
intact membrane preparations (Vauquelin et al, 1982 and
Teferences therein). We found only low affinity sites in 1%
igitonin-solubilized preparations: the Hofstee plots of the
competition binding (data not shown) were rectilinear, and
yielded 1C-SO values of 1.4 & 0.07 mM for carbachol and
0.45 & 0.04 mM for acetylcholine, Kp values, calculated
from the IC-50 values by the method of Cheng and Prusoff
(1973) and Chou (1974), were 0.70 + 0.04 mM and 0.23.
0.02 mM, respectively.
Purification of solubiliced mACHRs by affinity chroma:
‘ography
